R: @bjchambers
Doesn't build.

Added comments, mainly relating to @dhalperi comment on inheriting versions for root level pom (and some suggestions for additional once for Spark's pom).
BTW, is there an additional benefit here ? besides clarity of course. I'm not familiar with analyze-only.

And how does this relate to removing beam-examples dependencies ? Why do we want to remove this dependency ? I would prefer a dependency to use beam-examples in the runner's tests on duplicating them.

R: @mxm or @aljoscha 
CC: @amitsela 

The I/O stuff hasn't all been factored out from the core SDK yet, but I did realize that there are a number of useful tests that aren't run in any configuration.

I just added the config for KakfaIO here, mostly as an exercise & an example to see if it would be easy. I didn't look at any of the code under test or the test itself - I have suspicions that configuration changes might break it and/or make it too slow. At some point we probably want all of these to run with real clusters.

On the other hand, the whole point of the model/SDK/Runner API/Fn API/etc is that we should be able to develop these things in isolation with only selected integration tests. But for now, I'd say the more tests the better.

Users should be able to run beam-examples with any runners, and beam-examples will need runtime dependency to runners-spark. I cannot add that runtime dependency when runners-spark depends on beam-examples.

Previously, runners-spark is pull dependency from other module, and runners-spark can be broken by dependency changes in other module (removing, changing version, and even adding). This is another benefits.
R: @lukecwik
Should build now. I missed some Javadocs and a unique name.

(I'll look into build failures, hold off on review)

Rebase (now I won't rebase again, I will add new commits on the PR).
I have the following questions:
- from my understanding watermark is when the data is actually processed in the pipeline, compare to the timestamp which is when the data has been actually created. It allows us to deal with the skew (the gap between data creation time and data processing time). Correct ? So, in the JMS case, the timestamp is basically the message timestamp and the watermark is when the message is consumed from the broker.
- the checkpoint is an object holding the last data consumed. It's a kind of unique identifier for the message. In the case of JMS, I'm using the Message ID which is unique and generated by the broker. Correct ?
- I implemented the initial split reader using the executor recommendation.

To separate the syntax, we need the dependency to be the other direction. What today is `Trigger` will be moved to `runners-core`, while the syntax will remain in the SDK.

I've added also a reference to the "make runners-core a thing" Jira issue, as the drive to separate syntax from implementation is driven by that as well as the runner API.

Ah! Makes sense. Thanks for the explanation!

Generally, this PR makes me think hard about IOChannelFactory. I don't want us to have to add multiple versions of different sources just because one supports auth and one doesn't. [[BEAM-59]](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-59).

Any idea how hard it would be to integrate many of these into the same source, Neville or JB?
